Line 82: Line 82:
===Future of Windows===
===Future of Windows===
[[File:Windows 8 pre-release at D9 conference.png|thumb|250px|Screenshot of Windows 8 startscreen]]
[[File:Windows 8 pre-release at D9 conference.png|thumb|250px|Screenshot of Windows 8 startscreen]]
â
[[Windows 8]], the successor to Windows 7, is currently in development. Microsoft has posted a blog entry in Dutch on October 22, 2010 hinting that Windows 8 will be released in 2 years.<ref>{{cite news |title=Microsoft says Windows 8 roughly two years away |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13860_3-20020544-56.html?tag=mncol;title |work=CNET News |publisher=CNET |date=October 24, 2010 |accessdate=December 9, 2010}}</ref> Also, during the pre-[[Consumer Electronics Show]] keynote, [[Microsoft]]'s [[CEO]] announced that Windows 8 will also run on [[ARM Architecture|ARM]] [[CPU]]s. Since ARM CPUs are usually in the form of [[System-on-a-chip|SOC]]s found in mobile devices, this new announcement implies that Windows 8 will be more compatible with mobile devices such as [[netbook]]s, [[tablet personal computer]]s, and [[smartphone]]s.<ref>{{cite news |title=Next Windows to Run on ARM, Too|url=http://www.maximumpc.com/article/home/next_windows_run_arm_too |work=MaximumPC |publisher= Future US, Inc. |date=January 6, 2011 |accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref>
+
[[Windows 8]], the successor to Windows 7, is currently in development. Microsoft has posted a blog entry in Dutch on October 22, 2010 hinting that Windows 8 will be released in 2 years.<ref>{{cite news |title=Microsoft says Windows 8 roughly two years away |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13860_3-20020544-56.html?tag=mncol;title |work=CNET News |publisher=CNET |date=October 24, 2010 |accessdate=December 9, 2010}}</ref> Also, during the pre-[[Consumer Electronics Show]] keynote, [[Microsoft]]'s [[CEO]] announced that Windows 8 will also run on [[ARM Architecture|ARM]] [[CPU]]s. This windows version will also be more suitable for [[Tablet personal computer|tablet]]s and netbooks, featuring a more touch-friendly interface. Severeal new feature will also be introduced, like support for USB 3.0, and the ability to run Windows from USB devices (like USB Hard Disks or USB Flash drives), with [[Windows To Go]].
